discussion.title: Introducing new variables in custom loss function
discussion.body:
Hi Dr. Cranmer (or others),

For the PySR custom loss function (loss = "loss(x,y, w[optional]) = ") we specify in the model, right now it seems "x" is the data input while "y" is the analytic value found by PySR, and w are any weights the data has (which is optional), though please correct me if I misunderstood the variables (and this could potentially solve my problem).  However, if I'm using PySR to model something very specific (i.e. Poisson likelihood) and have a custom loss function that also depends on other variables ( data x = x(r), where I also want to include r in the loss function), is there a way to do this?  https://astroautomata.com/PySR/options/#loss has some nice examples of loss functions, but not introducing any other variables than the data "x" and fit value "y".
Thank you.

nodes.body:
Hi @quasars100,

The loss argument is of the form `loss(prediction, target)`. The evaluation used to create the predictions happens automatically using your passed data (a matrix of shape (examples,features)) and the current expression. Let me know if I misinterpreted your question though!

cheers,
Miles

Oh wait I think I misunderstood. Do you need weights *and* the radius r? If you only need the radius in the loss function, you can just treat it like `loss(prediction, target, r)=â€¦`, and pass `weights=r`. But if you need both, will be trickier. Let me know.
